contentrichtext.text: {{Italic title}} {{Infobox Weapon|is_vehicle=yes | name=''Flakpanzer IV "Wirbelwind"'' | image=[[Image:Wirbelwind CFB Borden 2.jpg|300px]] | caption=''Wirbelwind'' at CFB Borden | origin=Nazi Germany | type=[[self-propelled anti-aircraft weapon|Self-propelled anti-aircraft gun]] | crew=5 (commander/gunner, two loaders, driver, radio operator) | length={{convert|5.89|m|ftin|abbr=on}} | width={{convert|2.88|m|ftin|abbr=on}} | height={{convert|2.76|m|ftin|abbr=on}} | weight= 22 tonnes (48,501 lbs) | armour= 10 - 80 mm (.39 - 3.14 in) | primary_armament= 2 cm [[2 cm FlaK 30#2 cm Flakvierling 38|Flakvierling 38]] quad AA | secondary_armament=1x[[7.92 x 57 mm|7.92 mm]] [[MG 34|Maschinengewehr 34]] | payload_capacity= 3,200 rounds 2 cm<br />1,350 rounds 7,92 mm | engine=12-cylinder [[Maybach]] HL 120 TRM | engine_power= 300 PS (296 hp, 221 kW) | suspension=[[leaf spring]] | speed= 40 km/h (25 mph) | pw_ratio= 13.6 PS/tonne | vehicle_range= 200 km (124 mi) }} The '''''Flakpanzer IV "Wirbelwind"''''' ('''Whirlwind''' in [[English language|English]]) was a [[Self-propelled anti-aircraft weapon|self-propelled anti-aircraft gun]] based on the [[Panzer IV]] tank. It was developed in 1944 as a successor to the earlier self-propelled anti-aircraft gun ''[[Möbelwagen]]''. In the first years of the war, the [[Wehrmacht]] had less interest in developing self-propelled anti-aircraft guns, but as the Allies began to gain air superiority, the need for more mobile and better-armed self-propelled anti-aircraft guns increased. During the early summer of 1944, SS-''[[Hauptsturmführer]]'' [[Karl Wilhelm Krause]] with the [[12th SS Panzer Division Hitlerjugend|12th SS Panzer Division ''Hitlerjugend'']] came up with the concept of the ''Flakpanzer IV Wirbelwind''.<ref>http://www.achtungpanzer.com/flak4.htm</ref> He presented the concept to SS-''Obersturmbannführer'' [[Max Wünsche]], commanding officer of the 12th SS Panzer Regiment and it was approved by Hitler. The Panzer IV's turret was removed and replaced with an open-top, nine-sided turret which housed a quadruple [[2 cm FlaK 30#2 cm Flakvierling 38|2 cm ''Flakvierling'' 38 L/112.5]]. A closed-top design would have been preferable, but this was not possible due to the heavy smoke generated by the four anti-aircraft guns. Production of the tank was carried out by ''[[Ostbau Werke]]'' in [[Żagań|Sagan]], [[Silesia]]. Thereafter, the 2 cm shells proved less effective against aircraft so a more powerful successor was produced which eventually replaced it. Known as the ''Flakpanzer IV [[Ostwind]]'' (East Wind), the successor was equipped with a single [[3.7 cm FlaK 43]].<ref>http://www.achtungpanzer.com/flak4.htm</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Chamberlain | first = Peter | title = Encyclopedia of German Tanks of World War Two | year = 1999 | publisher = Cassell | pages = 110–111 | isbn = 978-1854095183 | ref = harv }}</ref> [[Image:Wirbelwind CFB Borden 1.jpg|thumb|left|''Wirbelwind'' at [[CFB Borden]]]] The combination of armor and rapid fire from the four guns of the ''Wirbelwind'' did make it effective against ground targets.<ref>{{cite book | last = Bishop | first = Chris | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = The Encyclopedia of Weapons of WWII: The Comprehensive Guide to Over 1,500 Weapons Systems, Including Tanks, Small Arms, Warplanes, Artillery, Ships, and Submarines | publisher = Sterling Publishing Company, Inc. | year = 2002 | location = | pages = 166–167 | url = http://books.google.com/books?id=MuGsf0psjvcC&lpg=PP1&dq=encyclopedia%20of%20weapons%20of%20world%20war%202&pg=PA166 | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-1-58663-762-0 }}</ref> Between 87 and 105 ''Wirbelwinds'' were produced during the war, but due to discrepancies between the recorded production numbers at the Ostbau Works and ''[[Wehrmacht]]'' service records, the exact number will probably never be known.<ref>http://www.achtungpanzer.com/flak4.htm</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Chamberlain | first = Peter | title = Encyclopedia of German Tanks of World War Two | year = 1999 | publisher = Cassell | pages = 110–111 | isbn = 978-1854095183 | ref = harv }}</ref> ==References== <div class='references-small'> <references/> </div> ==External links== {{Portal|Tank}} {{Commons|Flakpanzer IV}} * [http://www.panzerworld.net/flakpanzeriv.html Panzerworld Wirbelwind specifications] * [http://www.achtungpanzer.com/flak4.htm Achtung Panzer article on Flakpanzer IV] * [http://the.shadock.free.fr/Surviving_Panzer_IV_variants.pdf Surviving Panzer IV variants] -
